title: why would you say "cancer" in any kind of form in a video game?
body:
so.. i got a gank from  enemy gragas + nasus ... and i was playing teemo, so obvsiously i died ... 
anyway... it was the first blood of the game , and my diamond 5 vayne who played in low elo games , told me to get cancer ? 
like ... wtf?

replies.body: calling a item or champ cancer is fine, telling someone to contract it is complete Bull.
This pretty much.

Because children are attempting to make new lingo. "Salty," "Cancer," and a few other words are having their meanings changed..  or rather they are trying. Sadly we of generation X don't give a crap about this little rebellion of our children, unlike our parents did. Rather makes this rebellious streak a failure, and just look really stupid.

Cancer is actually pretty accurate. 

The etymology is basically as follows:
This champion/mechanic is unhealthy for the design of the game.
This champion/mechanic which is unhealthy is likely to spread through the game (infecting or metastasizing)
Cancer also spreads through the body through metastasis.

This champion/mechanic is cancerous.
From humanistic viewpoint, it's still not cool to use 'cancer' as a descriptive modifier for something as banal as a video game character. Ever.

That's your viewpoint, and I respect it, but I don't agree with it.

Regardless, the etymology is what I explained above, and it makes sense.
Why? It's not remotely the same thing as calling someone a slur based on their identity. Cancer is a bad thing.

Having anonymity is never an excuse for allowing behavior you would otherwise not in person. The internet is simply another form of (instant) communication; you wouldn't yell out "hope you get cancer!" over the phone to someone, etc.

On the same subject; go to a meeting of cancer survivors/family of cancer survivors, and say something with the phrase 'cancer' in it. See if anyone there is OK with using it as a descriptive modifier for your sentences.

When you experience life, you (usually) start to gain more appreciation and humility and compassion for others and their own struggles as well. Cancer isn't a joke, it's a serious disease that plagues millions just in the US.
